5.40.text:
>> DAVID NASSER: I was sitting in my office
earlier in the week, just preparing for my

8.68.text:
introduction of the Kelly family and, obviously,
the legend Jim Kelly, and Jill Kelly called

13.93.text:
and we started to have a conversation and
she just in passing mentioned, "Hey, Virginia's

18.94.text:
own NFL Hall of Fame inductee, you know, Bruce
Smith, is going to come and hang with us a

28.60.text:
She said, "He's just going to come and just
be in the area, he's good buddies with Jim

31.77.text:
and he just wants to come and hang out a little
bit," and as soon as I heard that I just thought,

36.14.text:
"We've got to have the guy who was on the
team with him.

39.29.text:
We've got to have the guy who saw this from
the front line just kind of be the guy who's

44.51.text: going to come and introduce him."

45.70.text:
And so, how amazing is it that we are blessed
today not just to have the Kelly family but

50.19.text:
the great Bruce Smith with us today, and we've
asked him to come and just say a few words

54.23.text:
and to introduce his great friend and his
family.

56.81.text: And so, Bruce, we're so honored to have you.

62.18.text:
And we had a helmet back there where we had,
you know, a sharpie and we wanted to get Jim

66.86.text:
to sign it but then we get to have two Buffalo
Bills sign it today.

69.67.text:
And so can we just put our hands together
for the great Bruce Smith.

73.19.text: Thank you, sir, for being here.

89.89.text:
I want to thank Liberty University for allowing
me this opportunity to come and say a couple

97.79.text:
of kind words about my beloved brother, Jim
Kelly, and his family.

106.99.text:
Jim and I have been teammates for all of his
NFL career, and I could talk about all of

115.04.text:
his accolades and his accomplishments--four
straight Super Bowls that he led us to, multiple

123.46.text:
Pro Bowls, one of the most prolific passers
in NFL history, first ballot Hall of Famer--but

133.88.text:
the most important thing to me is he is a
brother in Christ.

142.54.text:
He is a living testament of what God can do
for you in your life.

153.41.text:
As we watched that video, I lived that firsthand
with him.

160.44.text:
I saw his struggles, I saw his trials and
tribulations that he had to endure with his

167.85.text:
family, his son Hunter, and now his battle,
and even dating back to when his mother was

177.72.text:
diagnosed with emphysema, and I spent a considerable
amount of time with her.

185.50.text:
But I have such a great deal of respect, a
profound respect for my brother Jim Kelly,

198.22.text:
He is an incredible source of strength, encouragement,
his wisdom and knowledge over the years had

209.61.text:
His belief in God, his strength, and even
through these trails and tribulations, his

219.82.text:
And that's what's the most impressive thing
to me.

224.03.text:
During my trips to New York to see him in
the hospital, not being able to move, losing

231.51.text:
weight by the day, his wife and his kids by
his side every moment that they had, it just

241.23.text: showed what love, family, and God is about.

247.65.text: And it was incredible to witness.

251.58.text: Jim, Jill, Erin, Cameron, I love you guys.

262.30.text: I love you with all of my heart.

264.81.text:
I love you with the love of God, and I want
to thank you for allowing me to be a part

269.74.text:
of your life and to walk with you and continue
that relationship.

275.11.text:
It is so good to see you being able to get
around and move freely and talk and I know

283.09.text:
you're still not out of the woodworks, but
my love for you will be everlasting, and I

290.21.text:
thank you so much for this opportunity to
introduce my brother and my brother in Christ,

324.57.text:
Hey, remain standing just for a second, remain
standing.

We thought it would be very, very bad stewardship

337.43.text:
in the history of the planet, in the history
of history, and didn't have him at least throw

407.65.text:

560.17.text: What a great day it's already been.

Did that not just make your entire year, my

Well, just real quick, obviously, unless you've

578.08.text: living in a rock, are you kidding me?

579.94.text:
We have the single greatest quarterback that
ever hiked a ball and threw the ball four

585.36.text:
consecutive Super Bowls in a row, probably
will never ever happen again, but more than

590.44.text:
that we have a man who has been on this campus

595.36.text:
who's come to be a part of Convo or as a football

600.61.text:
as a great businessman, but really as a dad

605.18.text:
his own daughter and so, it is just good to

611.64.text:
Can you just tell us a little bit about your

616.30.text:
Wikipedia quick, where you started, just your

622.42.text:
I know you don't really want to brag but it
ain't bragging if it's true, all right, so

626.22.text: tell us a little bit about yourself.

627.22.text:
>> JIM KELLY: Well to make long stories short,
I grew up in a family of six boys.

632.40.text:
I was the fourth son and of course my mother
talked my dad into giving her one more try

636.58.text:
for a girl; had twin boys to make it six boys,
and throughout my career I was very blessed.

642.67.text:
I had a great mother and father, they pushed
us to a certain point but we knew what real

647.30.text:
respect was and as time went on, I really,
to be honest with you, wanted to play for

653.12.text:
Penn State, I wanted to be a quarterback for
Penn State--I don't cheer anymore for them

659.87.text:
because Joe Paterno said, "You know what,
we already signed our All-State quarterbacks

664.64.text: and we'll give you a scholarship as a linebacker."

668.20.text: And I said, "No thanks, I want to be a quarterback."

671.20.text:
So to fast forward, my red shirt freshman
year we traveled to Penn State; I'm the backup

676.10.text:
quarterback, and our coach at the time was
Howard Schnellenberger.

680.51.text:
And right before the game, right after pre-game
meal--I still haven't played a game yet--we're

686.33.text:
at Penn State in front of 90,000 people and
he came up to me and said, "Jim, we decided

692.02.text: we're going to start you today."

695.33.text:
He said, "Yeah, you've earned the right to
show us you can play," and first thing I did

700.87.text:
was I excused myself and I went into the bathroom
and I threw up for about 20 minutes.

706.98.text:
But we wind up beating Penn State and my first
four starts as a freshman quarterback--and

712.25.text:
I came from a little high school with only
60 in my graduating class, 23 players on my

717.17.text:
football team--Penn State, Alabama, Notre
Dame, and Florida, and that was my first four

724.67.text:
But thank God I went off and had a good college
career.

729.11.text:
My career ended in college against Virginia
Tech, which Miami beat last night.

737.29.text: And I blew up my right arm.

740.38.text:
Fourth game of the season, and they told me

743.58.text:
And one of the things that as, you know, as
a little boy growing up and my dream was to

747.63.text:
play in the NFL, to take care of the two people
I loved and that was my mom and my dad, and

751.54.text:
of course take care of my brothers also, and
they told me I would never play again.

755.77.text:
Well I got on my knees, I prayed, I continued
to pray and I worked very hard and I became

761.05.text:
the first-round draft pick of the Buffalo

766.47.text:
When the draft was held, and that was when

Baltimore, and they said, "Is there any teams

772.81.text: Now remember, I went to Miami of Florida.

I said, "Yeah, I don't want to play for Green

779.41.text:
Vikings, and I sure don't want to play for

783.25.text:
Needless to say the Buffalo Bills drafted

787.77.text:
to be honest with you, one of the greatest

793.11.text:

how of that just poured into your leadership

this was the Super Bowl years - to a party

And so, I was invited to the party and I went

we walked in and of course it was everything

The players were there, there were lots of
girls there, and all the other stuff that

881.23.text: >> NASSER: It was a Bible Study?

And so, eventually I was introduced to Jim,

895.49.text:
He's the quarterback that goes to the Super

899.36.text:
And we're excited and my friend and I, we're

902.35.text:
off because eventually he starts flirting

906.95.text:
And so he starts throwing ice cubes at me

So anyway, so at the end of the night he comes

921.31.text:

friend and I, we went up and we said, "Thank

that, and he said to me, he said, "Well, how

934.66.text:

No, no, no, we have the same version; he just

See the thing is, God was working in me before

there's no possible way that this guy can

972.27.text: I didn't give him my phone number.

It's so easy for girls, you put so much out

Well then I found out she broke up with her

where she worked and flowers, dinner, after,

1034.45.text:
That does pose a question as I'm hearing you

actually works in my department, she works

1044.72.text:

>> ERIN KELLY: But, I am completely trusting

1078.76.text:
really watched my parents and their relationship

1084.04.text:
lives and in their marriage and so, I completely

1090.95.text:
reminds me of during his chemo and radiation

1097.30.text:
"I might not have my dad to walk me down the

1101.49.text:
And that is one thing that was extremely hard
for me during that time was, that I wanted

1106.65.text:
my dad to be able to walk me down the aisle
and so it is such an answer to prayer and

1110.99.text:
I'm so thankful that he's sitting here right
now today and that one day he will walk me

1119.59.text:
Jim and Jill, I want to tell you, before we
move on from that little moment that we have

1126.27.text:
just been so impressed with the daughter that
God has given you the ability to raise and

1130.89.text:
she's such a great leader, a humble leader,
and whatever you did, please write a book

1136.11.text:
on that so that I can help raise my daughter
as you've raised Erin and you should just

1140.00.text:
be really, really proud of just the godly
example and leader that she is.

1143.67.text:
I know, though, that cancer wasn't the first
huge affliction moment, the first huge obstacle

1150.17.text: that you faced even in the midst of your marriage.

1153.43.text:
I know that obviously Hunter's story was all
over the news.

1158.80.text:
Even as a fan before I ever had the chance
to meet you I remember watching on ESPN, watching

1164.81.text:
all over the world just news media outlets
about how you guys were going through that

1171.68.text: Can you tell us a little bit about that?

1174.68.text:
Well, for most parents and most people that
plan on getting married, they plan on having

1180.54.text:
I came from a family, as I said before, six
boys, and when I retired from the NFL with

1185.65.text:
the Buffalo Bills in 1996, Jill was pregnant,
we'd already had Erin, and course I was hoping

1192.33.text:
for a son, and I remember the day when Jill
came to me, she said, "My water broke," and

1198.05.text:
I'm thinking, "Wow, it's Valentine’s Day;
it's my birthday."

1201.89.text:
So on the way to the hospital I automatically
thought, "Boy, wouldn't it be great to have

1205.05.text: a son born on daddy's birthday?"

1209.54.text:
Out pops Hunter and I was so excited, I don't
think there was a man on this earth that could

1216.87.text:
be as excited as I was, thanking the good
Lord for everything that He's given me, and

1221.40.text:
of course, you know, after taking him home
and being so excited and everything, finding

1227.48.text:
out four months into his life he was diagnosed
with a fatal disease called Krabbe Leukodystrophy

1231.57.text:
and from that point on I know that it was
tough on all of us and one of the things that

1238.74.text:
we learned was not to treat Hunter like he
was dying.

1242.64.text: To treat him like he was living.

1244.90.text:
We didn't know every day we woke up, we didn't
know--every day when we woke up, we didn't

1246.89.text:
know if our son was going to be there or not
the next day, and it was driving us crazy.

1251.74.text:
Then we decided, because the help of my mother-in-law
that, "Well let's treat Hunter like he's living."

1257.23.text:
So we started doing different things: horseback
riding with him, on a snowmobile course, some

1262.26.text:
off-roading after we snowmobile, and a couple
other things.

1266.21.text:
But our time during those moments was very
tough, and I know that I have to say, “Thank

1275.50.text:
the good Lord,” because we, as husband and
wife, it wasn't going very well and we needed

1282.53.text:
our faith and I can honestly say when I look
at my wife's eyes and speak that, I thank

1289.31.text:
the good Lord for her every day because she
not only had to go through what Hunter went

1294.44.text:
through for eight years, but now, come full
turn, now she has to take care of me and the

1299.88.text:
things that I've been going through, and she
is such a strong woman.

1304.27.text: She is such a strong woman of faith.

1308.01.text:
I know that the man's got to be the leader
of the house; she's the leader of faith in

1313.79.text:
She's what drives me each and every day and
through my tough times, you know we talk about

1318.85.text: the Kelly Tough and things like that.

1321.32.text:
I needed help, not only from a physical side,
which I grew up having, but for the mental

1328.94.text:
You always need somebody there, you always
need that support, and I had my wife, I had

1333.74.text:
my two daughters, I had my mother-in-law,
but more importantly I had the good Lord behind

1338.27.text: me, and I've never given up.

1339.62.text:
And for all those people out there--there
are kids out there having a tough time--remember,

1349.30.text:
I never ever gave up on anything I've ever
done in my life.

1352.57.text: And don't stop, don't stop just fighting.

1358.44.text:
Yeah there are days that we all have that
are not, you know, you don't wake up to the

1361.78.text:
sunshine every day, but I'll tell you what:
get on your knees and pray, because you never

1368.46.text:
And I live every day like it's my last, but
I enjoy every day.

1372.84.text:
So enjoy every day that you can and be blessed
with what you have.

1378.52.text:
What I love is--by the way, we're kind of
skimming through the top, and in your book,

1383.24.text:
Jill, as I was reading it, what I loved was
your transparency and your honesty in that

1387.85.text:
through what was happening with the birth
of your son Hunter and then discovering that

1392.82.text:
he's not just the colicky baby like Erin was,
alright, but that he actually maybe was going

1399.29.text:
through something or maybe had something and
then you start to get the news and it just

1403.18.text:
starts to unravel in front of you that not
only at that time--you really weren't living

1409.11.text: God wasn't in the center of your life.

1410.59.text:
You had a history, heritage of faith but you
really weren't living for the Lord.

1416.05.text:
And God, what I love about your book is you
said God didn't just use affliction and hard

1423.64.text: ship, you know, in my life.

1426.23.text:
God actually--that was the blessing, because
God actually used that really bring you back.

1430.38.text: Can you talk a little bit about that?

1432.73.text:
And, you know, when Hunter was diagnosed at
four months, obviously you don't forget that

1438.40.text:
I mean, I remember the weather, I remember
the smell of the room of the doctor when we

1442.05.text:
sat across from her at a table and everyone
that was there and, you know, when--and her

1447.53.text:
name was Doctor Duffner, and she said that
"Your son has been diagnosed with Krabbe Leukodystrophy.

1452.58.text:
There's no cure and there's no treatment and
he will probably not live to see his second

1458.30.text:
Mind you, God in His goodness and mercy and
grace and love allowed Hunter to live to be

1462.60.text:
eight and a half, but in that moment, you
know, all that I have in that moment is what

1470.41.text:
And all that I know in that moment is what
the world has taught me.
